Message.Title: Yahoo: Bernstein Says Value Could Top $25 A Share
Message.Msg: How much is Yahoo actually worth? That’s a more complicated question than you might think. It depends on two primary factors: the value of the company’s holdings in Alibaba and Yahoo Japan, and how much you think the core business is worth. Bernstein Research analyst Carlos Kirjner – who yesterday sparked a big rally in Facebook shares – has shifted his focus to Yahoo. He maintains an Overweight rating and $22 target on the stock, but asserts in a lengthy report this morning that the company could actually be worth $25 a share or more.

Message.Title: Bernstein Says Yahoo's Value Could Top $25 A Share

Message.Title: Yahoo: Bernstein Says Value Could Top $25 A Share
Message.Msg: How much is Yahoo actually worth? That’s a more complicated question than you might think. It depends on two primary factors: the value of the company’s holdings in Alibaba and Yahoo Japan, and how much you think the core business is worth. Bernstein Research analyst Carlos Kirjner – who yesterday sparked a big rally in Facebook shares – has shifted his focus to Yahoo. He maintains an Overweight rating and $22 target on the stock, but asserts in a lengthy report this morning that the company could actually be worth $25 a share or more. “A conservative valuation of Yahoo’s Asian holdings implies that the core business, whose fair value we believe is 5.5 times 2013 EBITDA, is currently valued at 2.9 times 2013 consensus EBITDA of $1.7 billion,” he writes in a research note. “We think this gap will close as the new management team reveals more of its strategy and reduces uncertainty, e.g., about future margins, as the core business posts results that show it is not declining (as a 2.9 times EBITDA valuation implies) and as shares get repurchased.” He also thinks 2013 consensus EBITDA estimates are too low, given that savings from headcount cuts announced earlier this year will accrue for all of 2013. Kirjner notes that his $22 target for Yahoo assumes a $40 billion valuation for Alibaba Group; that implies an after-tax value of $5.5 billion to Yahoo holders, or $6.3 billion – $5.37 a share – if you include the company’s Alibaba preferred shares. Kirjner contends that the current implied valuation for Yahoo’s core business implied a declining business – but he adds that while the coming is losing market share in core markets, it is simply growing more slowly than the overall market, and not shrinking. The analyst sees two ways the valuation could ratchet higher: Either the Asian assets are worth more than previous modeling suggests – or the core business is worth more than he’s been expecting. “It is hard to see Yahoo as a long-term winner, but … it is quite plausible that it could do better than expected from better and more investment in mobile, in video, in monetizing its audience, and in social,” he writes. “On the Asian assets, while there is potential for upside from Yahoo Japan, we think Alibaba is the most interesting asset. There is very little publicly available data on Alibaba Group, but we think it is possible (though not a slam dunk) to make a case for a higher valuation than the $40 billion.” Kirjner concludes that, in fact, Yahoo could worth $25 a share, “if you believe in the Alibaba story and are willing to give Yahoo the credit for that upside without a discount, despite the lack of transparency, the China risk, and, at least for the time being, the lack of liquidity. Or if you believe in a material turn-around of the core … In other words, we think it is plausible that Yahoo! could be worth $25/share, but it takes some faith.”

Message.Title: Is YHOO the most recent Goldman tech bubble like FB? Might be....
Message.Msg: Yahoo (NASDAQ: YHOO): A Losing Business to Avoid Yahoo is basically the complete opposite of Google. It has done very little over the years, and shareholder value has rightfully plummeted 31.4% over the last five years. Revenue opportunities also look quite weak. Yahoo is powered with Microsoft's Bing, and the results have been lousy in terms of international and mobile share. Google's desktop search share now stands at 83.6%, 10.7x Yahoo's slice of the pie. Now the rumor has it that Yahoo is looking to buy TVGuide -- how this will drive synergistic value, one can only wonder. Some claim that it may complement the Broadcast Interactivity platform, but at a valuation of as much as $25 million, the contribution is too little. Humorously, there are rumors that Yahoo is looking to partner with Facebook, a claim that the latter has dismissed. But, just like McDonald's insistence that it has "no plans for the bagged coffee market" (see here for result), corporate executives can (and, sometimes, should) say one thing and do another. In Facebook's case, I am not optimistic about what such a partnership could entail. After all, tying together two one-legged men won't make the result any more mobile. In general, Yahoo should be downsized and possibly sold. Shareholders have been calling on the CEO to announce job cuts and thereby limit the cost structure. But at 16x forward earnings and near its 52-week high, I don't believe the company can cut its way to outperformance. I like it when cost cutting is coupled with growth investments, and, in Yahoo's case, it isn't. For this reason, I recommend avoiding the stock.
